# Draft:Antonio Molina (historian)

Antonio M. Molina (19 November 1918 – 15 November 2000) was a distinguished Philippine historian, educator, lawyer, polyglot, and diplomat, renowned for his scholarly contributions to Philippine history and his role in fostering Philippine–Spanish cultural relations.
Early life and education
Born in Manila in 1918, Molina was the eldest of thirteen children born to Ricardo Molina, M.D., and Consuelo Memije
He completed his secondary education at Colegio de San Juan de Letrán (class valedictorian, 1937), obtained pre-law training, and earned his LL.B. from the University of Santo Tomas in 1940.
He passed the Philippine Bar in 1947. Awarded a Spanish government scholarship, he earned a summa cum laude Doctorate in Law from Universidad Complutense de Madrid in 1950
Academic and legal career
Molina joined the UST faculty in 1946 and served there for nearly 25 years. He held many leadership roles:
Dean, Faculty of Civil Law (1960–1966)
Director, Institute of History (1967–1970)
Vice-Rector for External Affairs and Secretary-General (1968–1970), making him the only layperson to hold these administrative posts
He taught Philippine history, civil law, ethics, philosophy, and Rizal studies
Diplomatic and post-academic work
In 1970, Molina relocated to Madrid, where he initially worked at Bufete M. Vega Penichet before joining the Philippine Embassy as press attaché and consul in 1971.
Language mastery and Scholarly contributions
A committed linguist, Molina spoke Tagalog, Spanish, and English fluently, and was proficient in French, Portuguese, Italian, and Japanese
The Philippines Through the Centuries (1961, two volumes): A landmark history text based on primary archival sources from Spain (Seville, Madrid) — a pioneering work in Philippine historiography
Historia de Filipinas (Madrid, 1984): Awarded the prestigious Premio Literario Enrique Zóbel in 1985
Dusk and Dawn in the Philippines (1996): A World War II memoir published by New Day Publishers
Yo, José Rizal (Madrid, 1998): A unique first-person biography of the Philippine national hero, based on original Spanish sources
Co-author of Hispanismos en el Tagalo (1972), a UN‑commissioned work for the International Year of the Book
He also authored other works, such as America en Filipinas (Madrid, 1992)
Awards and honors
Presidential Medal of Merit (1992) by President Corazón Aquino, recognizing his lifelong contributions to history and Philippine–Spanish ties
Awarded the Encomienda of the Order of Isabella la Católica in 1965, and became a corresponding member of the Real Academia Española in 1966
He was elected to the Philippine Academy of the Spanish Language in 1965
Legacy
In May 2019—on what would have been his 100th birthday—Molina’s family donated over 1,000 rare books and Spanish‑era archival materials to UST’s Miguel de Benavides Library. The collection, alongside an exhibit honoring his multifaceted career, is a valuable resource for researchers of Philippine history .
